title: Node.js & Express: Backend Fundamentals
content:
Module 4, Lesson 1: Node.js & Express — Backend Fundamentals

The Hook

Node.js brought JavaScript to the server, enabling full-stack development in a single language. Its non-blocking, event-driven architecture makes it excellent for I/O-heavy workloads — APIs, real-time apps, microservices. Express is the minimal, unopinionated framework that wraps Node's HTTP module with a clean API for routing and middleware.

The Concept

The Request-Response Cycle

Every Express app revolves around request (req) and response (res) objects. Middleware functions are executed in order, each calling next() to pass control to the next function. This pipeline pattern enables logging, authentication, body parsing, and error handling to be composed modularly.

Routing

Routes map HTTP methods and URL patterns to handler functions. Express supports route parameters (/users/:id), query strings, and nested routers. Organise routes by resource in separate files and mount them on the main app with app.use().

Error Handling

Express identifies error-handling middleware by its four-parameter signature: (err, req, res, next). Always define a global error handler at the end of your middleware chain. Never expose raw error messages to clients in production.

The Illustration

Node.js + Express is the most widely deployed JavaScript backend stack. Its middleware pipeline is composable and testable. Understanding request flow, routing, and error handling gives you the foundation to build any REST API.

options: A JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 engine that runs on the server

quiz.question: What is middleware in Express?
options: A function that has access to req, res, and next in the request-response cycle

quiz.question: What does app.use() do in Express?
options: Sends a response to the client
Mounts middleware or a router at a specified path
